docs.lead_paragraph: In recent decades, millions of working-age Mexicans have entered the United States. Most of them have come illegally, taking jobs on the bottom rungs of the American labor market. While much of the attention remains on the persistent inflow of illegal workers, a new question is beginning to worry some analysts and policy makers on both sides of the border: What will happen when the 10 million Mexicans living in the United States become too old to work? Will they retire in the United States or will they return to Mexico?

headline.main: Mexicans at Home Abroad; Will Millions Retire Here or Go South of Border?

docs.abstract: Social fabric on both sides of US-Mexican border could fray as Mexicans who entered US illegally reach end of their working years; Mexico, which has rapidly aging population and virtually no public system of social security or health insurance, can hardly cope with millions fo returning immigrants who spent their working lives in US; US is also unprepared to deal with millions of poor, aging immigrants, eking out living without recourse to Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid or most other forms of federal assistance, even though most of them have paid taxes over their working lives to these program; one factor that might keep older Mexicans in US is increasingly tight border security, which encourages illegal immigrants to settle in US rather than risk keeping families in Mexico and shuttling back and forth across the border; photos (M)
docs.snippet: As Mexican immigrants in the U.S. age, the choices they make regarding where to retire could fray the social fabric on both sides of the border.

multimedia.credit: As Mexican immigrants in the U.S. age, the choices they make regarding where to retire could fray the social fabric on both sides of the border.
multimedia.caption: Mexicans at Home Abroad

byline.original: By EDUARDO PORTER and ELISABETH MALKIN; Eduardo Porter reported from Donna, Tex., and Guerrero, Mexico, for this article. Elisabeth Malkin reported from Mexico City and Jalisco, Mexico

docs.lead_paragraph: Volunteering and working for an organization that serves children often means consenting to an extensive background check. Now that examination just keeps going -- and going.
docs.snippet: Nonprofit groups that work with children have begun using a technology that provides updates on criminal convictions among staff members and volunteers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones industrial average rose and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index held at a four-year high as oil prices fell from a record, helping the market recover from a weaker-than-expected report on the service economy. Microsoft led a modest rebound in the Dow average in the last hour of trading on speculation that new products would lift revenue and earnings growth. But disappointing results from Time Warner tempered optimism generated by generally robust second-quarter corporate profits.

headline.main: Shares Are Mixed, as Is the Underlying Economic News

docs.lead_paragraph: As traffic rumbled overhead, Omar Hassan captured the park skateboard competition at the Gravity Games in mid-July, winning on a course built in the shadow of Interstate 95. First prize was only $10,000 -- down from $25,000 a year ago. Still, Hassan took a victory lap by trying to spin one and a half times in the air and land on his skateboard, a maneuver called a McTwist. After several failed attempts, he limped away with a torn pant leg and a swollen left knee, using his skateboard as a crutch.

headline.main: Rad Dudes of the World, Unite

docs.snippet: Careers begun in rebellion against mainstream sports have developed some of the same workplace concerns addressed long ago in professional leagues and tours.

byline.original: By JERE LONGMAN and MATT HIGGINS

docs.lead_paragraph: Zero. That's the number of crunches Wendy Kaufman could do when she signed on to ''Celebrity Fit Club,'' VH1's reality show cum boot camp cum fat farm. Zero crunches, and thousands of viewers witnessed her mortification. But that was last season and more than 30 pounds ago, and this year, when ''Celebrity Fit Club 2'' was broadcast, the zaftig Ms. Kaufman -- known as ''Wendy the Snapple Lady'' in television commercials -- was up to nine crunches. The masses celebrated.

headline.main: The Humbling Art of Dieting for a National Audience

docs.abstract: Article on Celebrity Fit Club, one of several reality television shows featuring overweight celebrities; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Now that reality television has embraced diet culture, many B-, C- and D-list celebrities have signed up to lose weight in exchange for national exposure.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress is not expected to adopt deep changes to Social Security this year. But regardless of the outcome of Republican proposals to add private accounts to the system, the nation's huge life insurance industry stands to benefit from the debate over Social Security's future. Already, the debate has called attention to retirement concerns. Insurers have been increasingly focusing on selling investments for retirement and they are doing their best to capitalize on the attention. Moreover, if Congress does end up changing Social Security, there is a good chance any new law would favor the kind of investments called annuities that insurers love to sell.

headline.main: Insurers Want Their Say In Social Security Debate

docs.abstract: Life insurance industry steps up its lobbying over changes in Social Security, hoping to benefit regardless of outcome of Republican proposals to add private accounts to system; argues that annuities it offers can contribute to national savings and provide paycheck for life similar to Social Security, whereas flexible savings plan advocated by Pres Bush, which would probably take money away from them, would not increase long-term savings; also seeks to prevent elimination of estate tax, which many wealthy Americans now pay with proceeds of life insurance policies; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Regardless of the outcome of proposals to add private accounts to the Social Security system, the life insurance industry stands to benefit from the debate.

docs.lead_paragraph: People whose net worth is over $70,000, the median in the United States, are 30 percent less likely than poorer people to feel pain at the end of their lives, a difference that persists even when controlling for age and severity of illness, a new study shows. The findings, which appear in the August issue of The Journal of Palliative Medicine, used information on more than 2,600 adults over 70 who died from 1993 to 1998. The researchers interviewed proxies, usually surviving spouses, to gather information about pain, depression, delirium and difficulties in breathing or eating at life's end.

headline.main: Wealth Is Likely to Mean Less Pain at Life's End

docs.snippet: People whose net worth is over $70,000, the median in the United States, are 30 percent less likely than poorer people to feel pain at the end of their lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Liz Phair, former crown princess of indie music, has news for all those who wish she would go back to opening up a vein so listeners can feel her pain. She does not feel theirs.

headline.main: The Independence of Liz Phair; For Those Still Pining for the Old Sound, the Singer Says It's Time to Move On

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with singer Liz Phair, who comments on change in direction her music has taken and her latest album; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For those still pining for the old sound, Liz Phair, former crown princess of indie music, says it's time to move on.
